It was reported that Dr. Zijerdi was performing a primary hip surgery. During the procedure he broached to a size 13 corail broach. When he put the standard neck trial on the broach it did not slide on in the usual manner and he had to tap it on using a mallet. Also when he removed the neck trial from the broach he had to use an osteotome to get it off. The procedure continued without any other complications and he used a size 13 standard corail stem implant.
It was reported that he noticed the plastic snap ring was cracked after decontamination. Please send a replacement to our Knoxville office.

Received a report from a sales rep. "I have a certain who has had, he said six patients now that have had loose patellas and he doesn't even use our implant but he had used our cement. I'm not sure on how to do this i need to contact him for more information but i need to know if you could just advise me on what/how to approach this. Do I need patient name, what information and how do i go back in doing something which specifically I guess like this because it has happened I guess over several months ago and he's just on telling me about it now thinks its our cement for an implant that he's using which is not ours." He said all 6 patients were at the same hospital-which only had DePuy cement available. The surgeon has since asked for a competitor cement to be available for use. The surgeon said he might be able to get part/lot information and dates. If he is unable he will reply as such.

Instrumented/Navigated T12-S1 spine fusion: Hawkes Bay Hospital NZ 10/01/2019. (Loan) Kick Navigation System # 9, Serial Number 7405715001-18070. There were some serious inaccuracies in the Brainlab Navigation system that resulted in screws being placed in the incorrect level (L1 and not T12). There was also a medial breach of the pedicle due to poor screw placement and subsequent cement being injected around the dura. From DePuy Synthes side of things the case went well, instruments and implants worked perfectly fine and the surgeon was thankful for our support. We had a Brainlab rep there who ran the navigation. 60 minute delay to the procedure, No AE to patient. Patient Outcome Post Surgery: Patient doing well. Female patient aged 78 years.

Kick Navigation System S/N: 9269918001. Dr Anubhav Sathu, Mater Adults Hospital Brisbane 22/02/2019. TKR: During a primary total knee replacement the clicker attachment was found to be over-active when attempting to register anatomical landmarks at the beginning of the case. The computer would chime multiple times in an irregular pattern without being pressed and would then jump to the next point to be registered. The clicker was not stuck down and the registrations were disregarded as inaccurate. This resulted in the clicker being removed from the pointer and the clicker function being switched off. The case proceeded with a pointer-only technique to register points. The issue was repeated in the next case with the same result. There was a 5 minute delay to surgery for troubleshooting before a solution was agreed upon.

The primary surgery was performed (date of primary surgery was unknown). It was reported that the revision surgery was performed on Feb 13th 2019 by replacing the stem (P/N: 900549210) due to breakage of the stem. The stem was broken around at the one-third of the stem proximal side (9 mm) despite the patient did not fall during walking. The surgeon cut less than 10 mm of bone at proximal side of the sleeve 14B LAG with the oscillator and removed, and after struck the exposed sleeve inclined part with the hammer however it was not moved. The surgeon removed bone around the sleeve with the thin blade chisel and K wire and could not remove the stem even if the surgeon used the slap hammer nor other company's Grasper . Eventually, the stem was explanted by ETO. The metal liner was replaced to the poly liner 48×32 by MOM liner extractor, and the stem was bound with modulus cable. The MOM Pinnacle cup 48 mm× 28mm was not replaced. The surgery was completed. No further information is available.

It was reported that tibial bone trunk was fractured during TKA surgery by using the attune Revision PR tibial tray (P/N: unknown) on Jan 28th 2019. The cemented reamer tip interfered with the proximal tibial bone trunk and the tibia was fractured. The fracture was found by CT after surgery. The patient used steroids, so bone quality was bad, and it was quite fragile. It was considered that it may have interfered with the distal cortical bone because the cemented reamer was a little big. No further information is available.

It was reported that the cement (P/N: 3172080) back flowed to the pusher side of the gun in the syringe and leaked out during THA surgery on Feb 27th 2019. The surgeon used a foot pump according to the procedure manual as usual and set it to the cement gun after mixing. Although the cement viscosity was normal when it slightly released from the nozzle, the cement back flowed simultaneously with the injection into the femur and leaked out. The surgeon also used the pressure riser to complete cement injection into the femur and completed stem insertion successfully. The surgery was completed without a surgical delay and there was no adverse consequence to the patient. A considerable amount of cement adhered to the cement gun in the form of leakage when disassembling the syringe and the cement gun, and it was not able to completely remove it even it was washed carefully. No further information is available.

It was reported that during a total knee revision, the surgeon was broaching up to the desired femoral broach size when he was not able to extract the 35mm broach. When the surgeon attempted to remove the broach during a hit with the mallet the broach handle would disconnect from the broach. At that point the surgeon used the second broach handle in the set when he got the same result as before. Hitting the broach with the mallet during extraction of the 35mm broach would caused it the broach handle to disengaged leaving the broach in the patient. Unable to remove the broach with the broach handles the 1-3 broach adapter was threaded onto the broach then used as a hitting surface for the mallet to get the broach out. As a result the 3-1 broach adapter needs to be replaced because it was bent from removing the 35mm broach. No pieces of the instruments broke off during the procedure , therefore, no pieces had to be retrieved. All parts are being sent back to Depuy.

The patient was revised to address dislocation. The surgeon could not reduce the current implanted implants. Took the cup out and reamed up to a 55mm grater. Implated a 56 cup/40x56mm plus 4 10 deg liner and a -2 40mm head. DOI: Jan 17, 2019 DOR: Jan 17, 2019 Left hip
The PINN GB OFFSET GRATER HANDLE instrument was reported with unknown reason.

An unexpected issue arose today whilst covering a case for a colleague in Spire Elland. A request for loan equipment for Tc3/MBT by Spire Elland was made in Mid January, see attached booking. Attached images show the MBT tibial prep tray in which the surgeon wished to use MBT step wedges, Unfortunately these were not in the kit. However, the instruments to prep the step wedge are still there as seen in images below. We had to source step wedges locally prior to the case. The issue was when the surgeon wanted to trial. There were no option available to him. The only choice we had was to open two definitive implants in order to trial. Please can we arrange to have these two codes replaced at a cost to ourselves? 129456120 MBT Step wedge sz2 x5mm 129456121 MBT Step wedge sz2 x10mm This resulted in a short delay to surgery but no harm to patient. And caused significant stress to Mr Chakrabarty.
The patient was revised to address pain. DOI: Jan. 04, 2018 DOR: Feb. 25, 2019 Right Knee

Claim letter and medical records received. Claim letter alleges severe inflammation, severe pain, tissue and bone loss, metallosis and extremely elevated chromium and cobalt levels. After review of medical records, the patient was revised to address recurrent instability. During revision, some residual metal staining was noted from the notch on the femoral implant neck. There was also damage on the liner. The surgeon replaced the damaged liner with a 32mm +4 lateralized constrained liner. The 32 (+1.5) ceramic femoral head was also revised to a 32 (+1) ceramic head. DOI: Apr 28, 2014 - DOR: Nov 15, 2017 (Right Hip) This is the patient's 2nd revision. Previous surgery is on PC-000391230.
It was reported that the Straight stem inserter was bent and was having trouble disengaging from the stem. Surgeon asked it be replaced. No surgical delay.

Medical Records received. After review of medical records, it was stated that during revision surgery, the surgeon was unable to lay the locking ring properly on the liner even after multiple attempts. There was damage to the liner bending the overhanging edges which prevented the locking ring from being applied. A new constrained liner with a +10 degree posterior lip was implanted. There were no issues with the locking ring afterwards.
It was reported 30 mm flex drill bit broke while drilling for acetabulur screw. Broke halfway up flutes. No surgical delay

Upon explanting the Tibial component construct it became evident that the component was preoperatively misidentified by the surgical team as an MBT Revision Tibia and was actually an Attune Revision Component. No instruments or implants were immediately available for the Attune system. The Attending surgeon, while being advised of the off-label nature of his decision, decided it was in the best interests of the patient to implant a Sigma MBT Revision RP 15mm buildup Tray and to modify and utilize a Sigma TC3 RP Revision Insert to articulate with the size 3 Attune Revision Femoral component which resulted in a stable overall construct.

It was reported that during this case, the Doctor broached the femur incrementally starting with a canal finder, starter broach, and continuing broaches 1-4. Upon reaching the size 4, he reduced the hip with a high offset neck segment and a head. When he had brought it through range of motion and felt that the hip was rotationally stable and had no risk of dislocating he examined the interop X-ray to determine M/L fit of the broach in the canal. The 4hi stem was selected and opened. When inserting the stem, it was fully seated to the point where the broach sat and the collar was resting on the calcar. However, the stem was loose and not rotationally stable. The Doctor questioned wether the correct stem was opened - it was The stem was removed and the doctor was forced to broach up to a 5. He then chose the 5hi stem and it was opened. The 5 was inserted and was rotationally stable. Unknown affected side.

A literature article was received entitled "Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty for the treatment of failed fixation in proximal humeral fractures". The literature article indicates 6 patients had Reverse Total Shoulder Arthroplasty (RTSA) surgery after a failed fixation of a humeral fracture. The RTSA were placed between 2003 and 2016. One of the patients were noted to have died, but there was no mention of the date or cause of death. Of the 5 patients left, 4 were implanted with Delta Xtend, and one was implanted with competitor products. The study found one of the patient that was implanted with Delta xtend, was revised due to pain, stiffness, and decreased ROM. She underwent a glenosphere revision. 38mm standard to 42mm eccentric. Left Corail/PinnacleTotal Hip Replacement: John Mison, Lismore Base Hospital, 26/02/2019. The surgeon was drilling for pinnacle screws in a pinnacle sector cup. The 40mm drill bit bent during use. A 55mm drill bit was then selected, drilled and screw placed. The 55mm drill bit subsequently broke during attempted drilling of the next hole. The 25mm drill bit was then selected. This had difficulty staying connected to the flexible drill shaft and was disconnecting during use. It also subsequently broke during use. One screw hole was utilized only and the surgery proceeded. All components of the drill were removed from the patient. The surgeon suspects the drill may have perforated the medial wall of the pelvis during use, this was before the breakages. 5 minutes delay to the surgery. Patient ID: 03-96-25. Relevant Patient Pre-existing Conditions: Right total hip replacement.

The patient had a Right THA performed 11-21-08 using Trilock stem and ASR cup. This surgeon did a work-up he said, and found elevated blood setum metal ion levels. He wouldn't share with me what those levels were. But he did tell me that the patient wasn't experiencing any pain at all. In fact he said that the patient told him his Left hip, which is still a native hip, hurt alot worse than his Rt. The surgeon told me he felt that he needed to revise because of the blood test results. During the surgery, the surgeon told me that the hip and tissues looked normal. After removing the ASR 51 head and -1 sleeve, the surgeon said around the trunnion that there was trunnionosis. When he put the old ASR on the table, I could visually see some of the black marks he was referring to. The surgeon chose to use a S&N 51/28 dual mobility head and a Depuy ceramic TS 28 +5 head . The surgeon put in the real implants and was very happy with the stability, leg length and offset. He closed the patient up.

The primary surgery was performed in Sep 2003 by using LCS Universal via TKA (date of primary surgery was unknown). It was reported that the revision surgery was performed on Feb 27th 2019 by replacing all LCS Universal implants to other company's implants. It was planned initially to replace only the tibial insert or replacing by other company's implants due to instability at medial side of the patient's knee right joint. Although the surgeon explanted the tibial insert (P/N: unknown), and attempted trial reposition with the tibial insert trial, the surgeon recognized that the instruments did not fit because LCS Complete were prepared in error instead of LCS Universal. Since the implants were also mistakenly prepared by the LCS complete so the surgeon gave up on replacing the tibial insert. Therefore, the surgeon explanted all LCS Universal implants and inserted other company's implants, completed the surgery. Thus, there was about 60 minutes surgical delay. No further information is available.

It was reported that the surgeon set the patella resection guide setting in the wrong direction and resect bone of the patient's right knee during TKA surgery on Feb 15th 2019, thus the amount of bone resection was increased. It was originally planning to resect with 9mm and to keep 14.5mm because the patella thickness was 24mm. Since the surgeon mistakenly oriented the patella resection guide in the wrong direction, the patella was resected by leaving 9.5 mm, and it was resected with 5mm more than the original plan. The surgeon recognized this issue when inserting implants. It is recommended to keep 12mm or more of the patella, however as a result that it became less than 12mm. The surgery was completed without a surgical delay and there was no adverse consequence to the patient. No further information is available.

It was reported that the patient presented with a red & swollen left knee due to a fall. The patient has a LCS total knee replacement in that knee and the surgeon suspected either a fractured patella or torn tendon. The surgeon opened the left knee capsule, removed the LCS metal-backed patella, re-drilled the three peg holes, and cemented on a new, size large, all-poly, LCS patella implant. He then reinforced the patella tendon with FiberWire suture, irrigated the wound with copious amounts of saline and Irrisept, performed a range of motion exercise, and finally, closed the wound. Because this was a recent traumatic injury, the surgeon did not suspect infection and he did not send joint fluid or tissue specimens to the lab. The patient was generally healthy with few allergies and/or co-morbidities. DOI: 8 years ago DOR: Feb 15, 2019 Left Knee

It was reported that the patient had a Right THA performed approximately 20 years ago. The surgeon felt from X-ray that the patient had developed poly wear. After the surgeon sent me a picture of the X-ray, it was determined to be an Srom stem and Srom cup. During the surgery, the surgeon removed the Srom liner and 2 locking pins. There was significant poly wear, but the surgeon didn't think it was excessive considering it has been in approximately 20 years. The surgeon was able to identify the poly as a M series. He trialed a 10deg trial and liked the stability and leg length. He implanted the new 28mm 10deg m series liner and used 3-5.0 liner locking pins. He also used a ceramic Srom head 28mm +0. He was happy with the outcome of the surgery. DOI: Feb 01, 1999 DOR: Feb 15, 2019 Right Hip

The primary surgery was performed in Nov 2018 (date of primary surgery was unknown). It was reported that the spin out occurred after 3 months of the primary surgery. The patient visited the hospital for reduction of the spin out however it was not able to resolve. Thus, the revision surgery was performed on Feb 13th 2019 to thicken the tibial insert (P/N: 151630305). The surgery was completed without any problems. The surgeon considered that it might be the spin out occurred because of the insert lip was shallow, and the insert restraint was low. The sales rep opinion that it was chosen the thin insert despite there were large amount of cutting bone in the primary surgery and as a result it might be there was a space between the femoral component and the tibial insert, and the spin out occurred. No further information was provided by the hospital.

It was reported that the patient presented with a red, swollen & painful left hip. The surgeon performed a total hip arthroplasty just four days prior on this patients same left hip and he suspects infection. Today, the surgeon opened the left hip capsule, retrieved both fluid and tissue specimens for the lab, and then proceeded to remove the femoral head, then the poly liner and stem. The surgeon then irrigated the wound with copious amounts of saline solution w/antibiotic while waiting for the lab report. He then implanted a new poly liner, a new Actis femoral stem, followed by a new ceramic femoral head. The lab report came back positive for infection. The surgeon irrigated with Irrisept chlorhexidine gluconate and closed the wound. It was also reported that there was loosening of the pressfit stem at the bone to implant interface. DOI: February 4, 2019 DOR: February 8, 2019 Left hip.

The surgery was completed by using alternative drill tip (P/N and lot number were unknown). There was less than 30mi. surgical delay and no harm to the patient. No further information was provided by the hospital.

The surgery was performed on Mar 13th, 2019 via TKA. It was reported that the tibial insert (P/N: 151640405) did not fit tibial base implant. There was less than 1 mm gap, but no material was remained between them. The surgeon used another tibial insert (P/N: unknown) with the same size which fitted the base properly. The surgery was delayed by less than 30 minutes. There was no adverse consequence to the patient. The investigation was requested whether the device has met the standard value. No further information is available.
It was reported that the Spring broke on reamer handle. No surgical delay.
Pinnacle reamer handle - D255000140, lots# T17652 or PC3913146. End of reamer handle (coupling end) is worn/damaged/sharp and no longer couples into Hudson Q/C. Likely has been worn over time.

Total Knee Replacement; Dr. Des Soares, Greenslopes Private Hospital 15/03/2019. During this procedure, a drill pin was inserted into the block, to fix it to the bone.... it was found to be slightly bent, resulting in it jamming in the pin slot.... "cold welded", unable to be removed. 5 minute delay to the procedure. Alternate cutting block sourced from another set. No AE to patient. Male patient initials J.R., DOB: 18/07/1950
It was reported that the Office sets instrument was worn and cannot read. No surgery was affected.

Total Hip Replacement; St Vincents East Melbourne 05/03/2019. The surgeon selected the correct sized femoral head after trialling and asked for a 32 + 5 ceramic. The box was completely wrapped with the tabs still in place and when opened there was no implant inside the box. After some searching for the correct implant the surgeon decided to use a metal head 32 + 5. Action taken to manage the problem: Rep at the time adapted quickly and got replacement implant from nearby hospital. 10 minute delay to the procedure. No AE to patient.

Expires 03/2019 151641012 ? Expires 06/2019 151621005 ? Expires 07/2019 151621006 ? Expires 04/2019 151621007 ? Expires 02/2019 151621008 ? Expires 03/2019 151621010 ? Expires 03/2019 151621012 ? Total Knee Replacement: St Vincent's Hospital (Lismore), John Mison, 12/03/2019, Brainlab navigation machine, Binalong Bay, serial number 8860114001, was booted up prior to a case commencing. The machine refused to boot up and displayed the message 'enter password' in a blue box. Unable to call up a keyboard or enter any password. Machine was rebooted twice with the same error message occurring. It was also noted the grey cable that attaches to the camera was damaged. Surgeon was notified prior to commencement of the case, and was irritated, but was able to complete case using an instrumented workflow. This error was discovered prior to the commencement of the case and there was no delay to surgery. No AE to the patient, No delay in the surgery.

Patient was revised to address pain which was the result of the fraying of the rotator cuff over time. After removing the Humeral stem, a long stem Delta Xtend was cemented in place and Metaglene and Gleonsphere placed on the native Glenoid. Stability was maintained with a 38 + 6 mm Humeral Cup. DOI: several years ago DOR: Jan 30, 2019 Unknown affected side

The original DePuy implant was carried out at Spire hospital Cardiff U.K. in 2007.I understand it was a DePuy corail pinnacle.We were contacted by Spire in November 2017 advising us that ALL metal implants were being reviewed by N.H.S.U.K.we contacted their helpline but had no reply.Because of our concern we had blood tests done privately,they showed a very high cobalt level. N.H.S.Spain told us it would take several to get an appointment just to see a specialist.We decided to seek private medical advice. We went to see the Surgeon at Quiron Hospital Torrevieja Alicante Spain .After scans and blood tests he advised us to have the original implant removed.This was carried out in Jan.2018 at a cost of 21,000euro. At this moment in time we have spent approx..24,000euro. My wifes rehabilitation is still ongoing,her mobility is severely restricted and she still has to use a wheelchair or walking stick.

It was reported that Dr. Peterson's patient presented with pain in right hip area. She had previously had Dr. Peterson perform a total hip arthroplasty on that same side in January 2019, approximately five weeks earlier. Dr. Peterson opened the hip capsule, removed a femoral head, poly liner. 6.5mm dome screw, hole eliminator, and finally, a loose Sector cup. He would not elaborate on why he thought the cup was loose but it seemed on x-ray to be pushed deep into the pelvis. If I remember correctly, he said the patient had fallen recently. No specimens were sent to the lab because the hip was not infected. We replaced all parts removed with a Pinnacle revision cup, several screws, a new poly liner, apex hole eliminator and revision ceramic femoral head. The wound was irrigated with copious amounts of Irrisept and closed. DOI: Jan 21, 2019 DOR: Mar 3, 2019 Right Hip

Smotth headless Steinmann pins were used to hold the femoral cutting block in place. When using the saw to perform bone cuts, one of the smooth pins migrated/vibrated out and fell on the floor. Both pins were replaced assuming they had both fallen on the floor but it was later discovered that one had gone through the block and entered the femoral IM canal and was unable to be retrieved in patient. This is an experienced surgeon who has never experienced anything like this before. Foreign object retained in patient. The patient was revised to address instability. The previous surgeon implanted a TC3 RP tibia with sleeve and stem but a PS femoral component. The revising surgeon decided it would be best to revise femur to a stemmed TC3 component and implant a TC3 insert, instead of a PS insert. Removal of PS femur was successful with minimal bone loss. A TC3 Sz 3 femur was prepped with a 16x75mm press fit stem. A trial reduction was done with 10mm TC3 insert and found to be satisfactory. Real implants were opened, assembled and implanted. The surgeon ran the leg through range of motion once more and was happy with final implants. DOI: Unknown DOR: Mar 15, 2019 Left Knee

The primary surgery was performed on Jan 16th 2019 via TKA by using Attune PS Fixed (the PS Femour #6, the Fixed Tibia #6, the PS Fixed Insert #6, the 7mm patella 38mm). The surgeon recognized at CT that the tibial insert was dissociated in the anterior direction and the patella was cracked when the patient visited to the hospital and complained the pain on Mar 1st 2019. Thus, the revision surgery was scheduled to be performed on Mar 6th 2019. It was planning to replace the tibial insert to thin insert, and to wiring and pinning the patella or replace according the situation of the patella. The surgeon commented that it would be considered as cause of the patella was cracked and the insert was dissociated because the patella pressure was high and also the knee was tight in flexion and the tibia was rotated in the internal. The surgeon considered that it was not a defect of the product and it was a technical problem. No further information was provided by the hospital.

The BHA surgery was performed on Mar 18th, 2019 by using the C-StemAMT. It was reported that the cement restrictor trial (P/N: unknown) was stuck inside the medullary cavity when the surgeon attempted trial test. The surgeon decided to use the cement restrictor #5 even the sales rep advised the cement restrictor #4 was suitable size. As a result, the cement restrictor #5 was stuck inside the medullary cavity, so the surgeon destroyed the cement restrictor #5 with the reamer and removed. Therefore, the surgeon eventually implanted the cement restrictor #4. The surgery was completed and there was no adverse consequence to the patient. It was unknown whether there was a surgical delay or not. No further information is available.

It was reported that the blade of the tibial cemented conical reamer (P/N: 250620103) was caught in the SRI ATTUNE stemable tibia tower (manufactured by KSI) and it was stuck and the fixed tibia plate was come off during TKA surgery on Mar 18th, 2019. The surgeon re-placed it and repeated the same process. However, the blade and tower were scraped, and the metal powder was appeared. Thus, the surgeon stopped using the instruments to prevent health damage to the patient. The surgery was completed within a 30 minutes surgical delay. There was no adverse consequence to the patient. It seemed to be an issue of accuracy of the tibia tower and the conical reamer. No further information is available.

Information from a patient came from Medical Affairs with MIR No. 4487:?In 2015 I received a knee implant (right side, TEP) and had to undergo revision surgery in 2018 because the tibiaimplant had loosened. I have to also mention that I have an implant of your company in my left knee (since 2011) and this implant does not cause any problems. We are looking for the cause why the mucose membrane on my right knee is so reactive? We have no further information

Washout for infection, James Reidy, Gold Coast University Hospital 13/03/2019; Patient underwent primary THR on 16/12/2003 ( Dr James Sullivan; hospital not known (Sydney). Patient has presented at the Gold Coast university hospital with high fever and pain around the hip. Patient has reported feeling progressively worsening pain around the hip for 2 weeks prior to presenting with high fever). Hip was opened up and copious amounts of puss were present. The head and liner were temporarily removed and the joint was debridemont and washed out. The head and liner were then implanted and the patient closed. Male patient initials R.G.

MAUDE Report received: As states, "Loosening and failure of tibial component of DePuy attune total knee replacement implant over 3 years. No bonding between implant and cement with progressive loosening and varus collapse of implant and significant bone loss. Revision total knee replacement showed completely unbounded tibial component with complete cement mantle intact and nothing on the tibial component. The femoral component was also loose but has some bonding. Patella button was well fixed. The significant tibial bone loss, worse medially than laterally, required augments as part of the revision surgery. After seeing this case and many other similar early faulires, as an orthopaedic surgeon specializing in primary and revision total knee arthroplasty, I believe there is a problem with the implant and it should not be used in patient." DOI: Jun 12, 2015 DOR: Feb 26, 2019 Unknown affected side

It was reported that the instrument was found non-functional at the office. This modular stop (254600500) will not fit over any reamer that they had tried it on. They had tried multiple reamers 250620102 & 250620103 a total of 4 different sets of reamers. On reamers 250620102 the modular stop will pass over the initial part of the reamer however it will not continue into the modular stop path of the reamer. They had pictures of this if it will help. With reamer 250620103 the modular stop will start into the modular stop path but only half of the stop makes it into the channel, then it stops. Again they had pictures. They had tried flipping the modular stop around and the same it true with both sides.

Death case. This case is from health authority. It was reported that patient accepted Artificial femoral head replacement on 8th Feb,2019. The patient was unconscious after cement was implanted in 1 min. It was noted blood pressure decreased and heart rate slew down. Expansion and chest compression were treated immediately. The patient was moved to ICU after vital signs were stable. Then patient was dead since decline of blood pressure and heart rate. CPR failed to save patient as well and finally patient family gave up treatment.

An article/literature was received entitled "Bipolar Hip Arthroplasty as a Salvage Treatment for Instability of the Hip" The purpose of the study was to evaluate the results of bipolar hip arthroplasty for the treatment of recurrent instability of the hip. The DePuy Self-Centering bipolar hip device was used in one case, identified as Case 15 within the study group. This patient experienced a single complication of hip dislocation within one week of bipolar implantation, requiring conservative treatment via non-invasive immobilization (hip spica cast or hip immobilizer brace--not specified) which was successful in providing a stable hip from that point on. The patient did not require a revision surgery. The authors did not provide product or lot code information for the Self-Centering device, nor any details with regard to femoral head or stem, bone cement used, etc.

It was reported that the patient had a LT THA done approximately 10 years ago. The surgeon didn't know any information regarding the primary surgery. The surgeon told me that the patient fell back in October 2018. He believes from examining the patient and seeing her X-rays that she had significant poly wear. Once the surgeon opened the patient up, he immediately told me he saw a lot of metal debris. He also began picking out pieces of poly. The surgeon at that point said he believe that the poly must have cracked or something when the patient fell. Even with the poly being in pieces, he said the hip was stable. There was minimal damage to cup. The surgeon put in a 32/48 +4/10 liner and the liner fully seated. He then trialed a 32 +5 head. He was very happy with both leg length and offset. He implanted a ceramic TS 32 +5 head and began to close. DOI: Mar 2, 2009 DOR: Mar 4, 2019 Left Hip

MAUDE Report Received: Hip replacement surgery with Depuy MOM Pinnacle right on above date. Continued pain, difficulty walking with clicking, squealing, popping, heavy metal screening of the blood done in 2012. Abnormally high levels of cobalt and chromium. Revision surgery done in 2012 with removal of the ball with replacement of ceramic. The socket was lined with heavy duty plastic and left in place. Muscle damage surrounding the prosthetic left me with weakness and continued pain. Sudden pain developed in (B) (6) 2016. MRI showed fractured screws in the socket and rubbing it on the pelvis. One broken off screw still in pelvis. Continued chronic pain, Gait disturbance and inability to walk up stairs and do other movements due to the muscle damage. I'm also at an increased risk of a hip dislocation.

Revision Hip Replacement; Dr Cameron Cooke, Princess Alexandra Hospital 15/04/2019. A revision of a competitor prosthesis was performed on Monday 15/4/2019. During implantation of the LPS prosthesis, surgeon used the LPS disassembly tool with the intention of altering the version of the prosthesis. The teeth of the tool broke off in situ and the disassembly tool was unable to be used for its intended purpose. All metal particulate was cleared from the surgical site and the surgeon was satisfied that it was safe to continue. There was no alternative tool available. An alternative solution was found to achieve the intended result without disassembling the prosthesis. The debris was cleared from the surgical site, 5 minute delay to the procedure. No AE to patient.

The surgeon was impacting a corail stem and decided that the version was different to what he had broached for, so stopped impacting, attached the threaded stem insertor and backed the stem out with the mallet. He had to take the stem and insertor back out and reimpact a new stem with the non-threaded insertor. It was reported that the premature curing of the cement (P/N: 3172080) occurred during the TKA surgery on Apr 19th, 2019. There was no problem to use the cement for the component after about 2 minutes and half that was mixed, however the cement was started to cure when the surgeon used the cement for the femur after about 5 minutes that was mixed. Although the surgeon attempted using the cement quickly for the patella, it was not possible. Thus, the surgeon had to use the endurance bone cement 40g too. It took for 11 minutes to cure the endurance bone cement 40g. The surgery was completed about within 10 minutes surgical delay. Both of the cements were delivered to the agent two days before the TKA surgery, stored one day at the agent warehouse, transported to the hospital operating room the previous day of the TKA surgery, and it was the same storage conditions until use. No further information is available.

It was reported that while assembling the revision component (parts listed below) the lateral posterior augment combo failed to screw/lock into the Femoral TC3 component. After multiple attempts by 2 experienced people, a second augment was opened; this augment also failed to lock into the Femoral component. With both pieces, when they attempted to torque the screw with the torque wrench, the augments lifted away from the femur. Both the surgeon and the assistant (a former DePuy rep) are well versed in assembling these components. Distal augments were placed prior to the attempted placement of the posterior augments as is customary. The conclusion was that the threads in the Femoral component were not right. One of the posterior augments was subsequently cemented onto the femur and the entire component was cemented into the patient. All other augments 3 additional) were assembled in the normal fashion. The stem also went on with no issues. There was a surgical delay of 15 minutes.

MAUDE Report received. As stated " Eleven and half years ago I had a metal on metal hip replacement (DePuy). Over the years, my cobalt level rose to a 5. On the above mentioned date. I had it fixed. In the last five months the Cobalt has drained out of my system and my Chromium is at a .9. What bothers me is the initial Doctor who put the replacement in never followed up to tell me or anyone else that there us a problem. U know there are more than 1 million people in the US who could benefit mentally and physically if they insisted. As I did on getting their blood tested several times each year. This is not something that is initiated by Doctors. I feel blessed that I have the moxie to take my healthcare into my own hands. I know there are scores of others who do not know to do this.On 2007 initial Hip replacement.on 2018 Hip replacement. I have two hips replacements." DOI: Jun 09, 2007 DOR: Oct 22, 2018 Unknown affected side

Synostosis at the distal end of the stem was severe and could not be removed with a slap hammer, and also it could not be removed with a chisel. The surgeon attempted to remove via ETO, it could not be removed. As a result, the condition of at the proximal femoral got worse because there were also screw holes, the surgeon replaced from the stem in question to the S ROM A stem. The surgery was completed 60 minutes delay. No further information is available. We went attention to the sales rep to comply with the prescribed reporting date.

The primary surgery was performed on Nov 20th, 2018 via THA by using the stem (P/N: 3L92500). It was reported that fracture occurred at distal part of femur which was under the stem on Nov 26th, 2018 thus, the plate fixation surgery was performed.

It was reported that while inspecting the ATTUNE instrument set after they came out from the washer/sterilizer, The staff noticed a very small chip missing from one of the posts of the spacer block. The springs were still attached and all four posts were still attached. The spacer block was removed from the set because one retention spring could possibly work it's way off of the broken post. The chipped piece of plastic was never found. It could have been washed away in the washer. To Recap: A small piece of one of the four posts on the ATTUNE spacer block was missing after coming out of the washer/sterilizer, following an ATTUNE total knee. No one noticed it during the case, so it could have been chipped off during the washing process. The case was not delayed. All four retention springs were still intact on the four posts. No one noticed the chip missing during surgery. Note: This spacer block has been retained for your inspection, if requested.

MAUDE Report Received. Hip replacement surgery with Depuy MOM Pinnacle right on above date. Continued pain, difficulty walking with clicking, squealing, popping, heavy metal screening of the blood done in 2012. Abnormally high levels of cobalt and chromium. Revision surgery done in 2012 with removal of the ball with replacement of ceramic. The socket was lined with heavy duty plastic and left in place. Muscle damage surrounding the prosthetic left me with weakness and continued pain. Sudden pain developed in 2016. MRI showed fractured screws in the socket and rubbing it on the pelvis. One broken off screw still in pelvis. Continued chronic pain, Gait disturbance and inability to walk up stairs and do other movements due to the muscle damage. I'm also at an increased risk of a hip dislocation. DOI: Jun 09, 2005 - DOR: Jun 21, 2016 (Right Hip) (Cup and 3 screws)

Medical records and sticker sheets received. After review of medical records, it was stated that the patient underwent I&D on 06/2/2008 to address post operative infection. However, patient was brought again to OR for a revision surgery and implantation of antibiotic spacers. Revision notes reported that copious amounts of serosanguineous fluid was retrieved. There was no pus and no necrotic tissue present. Multiple attempts were done to remove the stem but these were unsuccessful so an extended trochanteric osteotomy was elected. A fracture occurred at the level of the vastus tubercule. Afterwards, the stem was removed successfully. The stem was not grossly loose. It was also indicated that the patient had a mild leg length discrepancy in the left versus the right. DOI: Apr 14, 2008 - DOR: Jun 6, 2008 (Left Hip)

ASR Medical Records and sticker sheets received. After review of Medical Record, it was stated that the patient was revised to address pain, non-ingrowth of the acetabular component and adverse reaction to metal debris. Revision notes reported that the acetabular component have very minimal tissue ingrowth and was essentially nearly fully non-ingrown which cause patient pain. Most of the surface of the cup had a thin fibrous filmy covering with extremely sparse area of apparent bone contact. Cup and head were removed to replace the bearing. Minimal dissection with an osteotome between the acetabular rim and the bone completely loosened the cup and it essentially fell out of the bone. Scar tissue was also removed. It was reported that the patient underwent total hip arthroplasty on the left hip several years ago. A DePuy SROM stem and Pinnacle Cup along with an Ultamet Metal on Metal bearing was implanted in the patient. Patient complained of pain and it was determined that a revision was needed. Patient underwent revision total hip surgery on 4/9/19 at Weiss Memorial hospital. Upon opening of the fascia, brownish tissue was observed. A pseudo tumor was observed. Head was removed and a mild amount of black "corrosion" could be seen around the inside of the 36 mm head and on the trunion, but not a trememdous amount to be concerned of the trunion of the stem. Ultamet liner was removed using the Pinnacle Constrained poly removal tool. Cup was in good condition and a poly liner was then inserted as well as a Ceramic SROM head. Due to the amount of pseudo tumor and and suspect looking tissue, the doctor determined it was an adverse reaction to the metal on metal articulation. DOI: unk DOR: Apr 9, 2019 Left hip

I just wanted to bring to your attention that the last 3 cases we have done with Dr. Glasson we have ended up using different sizes than the trumatch plan. 1 of those we went to a larger size femur & the other 2 were tibial trays- 1 we went up a size & the other we went down a size. In addition to sizing, 2 of these cases we had to take additional bone on both the distal femur & the proximal tibia. I am only bringing this to your attention b/c I know Trumatch has changed some things & I don't know if there is a different process or software in place that could be potentially causing this. We very rarely change the proposed size, especially on the femur! I think overall it's only happened maybe 3-4 times in the past 4 years

It was reported that the when preparing for a femoral sleeve and after engaging the bone with the first broach, every time we tried to back it out, the broach handle would disengage from the broach. We had a second sterile femoral broaching tray so we swapped the broach and broach handle but it gave us the same result. We did bur out some bone by the clasp junction thinking maybe the bone was causing and issue but it did not help. Overall, it probably added 10-15 minutes to the case. The surgeon had never had that problem before and believes that the amount of force holding onto the broach may have not been enough for a patient with excellent bone stock.

Patient was revised due to failed implants and loosening of the femoral component at cement to implant interface. Cement manufacturer is unknown. There was no visible cement on the backside of the femur/augment construct. The femur came out with the bolt (not broken and not attached to the femoral adaptor). The adaptor came out without evidence of having been cemented and had the threaded section of the stem broken off inside of it. The pressfit stem (115?) x 14? had to be extracted using trephines. The stem had been cemented into the canal. The FB tibial baseplate and stem (looks like 75mm in length) were extracted together with great effort. The stem and baseplate were cemented in. The polyethylene had visible divots and gouges in the spine aspect of it. All components were removed from the patient. Extreme metalosis was visible upon entering the joint capsule. DOI: Feb 05, 2010 DOR: May 02, 2019 Left Knee

The incident only delayed the case for a few minutes, since he had a joint replacement fellow assisting him with the case. The fellow continued on from where Dr. McAsey left off, until The Surgeon was able to rejoin the case. The xray picture attached (although not exactly perfect image-projections) has raised great doubts, as ASR has no fixing screws, and in any case the profile is rounded so not corresponding to the ASR profile. Our ASR program director asked herself if it was a Pinnacle (or another cup of similar spherical profile). she wondered if the stem was really Corail from DePuy or maybe a copy, perhaps with a modular neck (fracture line would correspond to the point of insertion of a modular neck). Olimpia Bona ASR Program Director sent an email to Leeds asking for R&D help / confirmation on reading the plate. As per email that I am attaching, the following was detected from Simon Cawthan Senior Design Engineer Outsourcing: - confirmation that it should be a CORAIL high offset (KHO) and if of size 13 as per the label the head is then a 36 - confirms that if DePuy is Pinnacle with Ultamet insert (I can confirm that from my data there are Pinnacle Ultamet invoices to Frate Sole) The patient will undertake a new revision.

It was reported that as the surgeon was trying to implant a DePuy, cancellous, 6.5 bone screw into the a new, acetabular, Gription cup, the ratcheting screwdriver "stripped" and would not turn the screw into the bone. There were no loose pieces, and the case was not delayed, because we quickly opened another screw set, and handed the surgeon another driver. To recap: The ratcheting screwdriver handle in our set would not advance the bone screw. The ratcheting mechanism stripped out. Only one instrument broke and no parts or pieces fell into the wound. The case was not delayed in any way. A different screwdriver was used to finish the surgery. This instrument has been retained and is available for your inspection, if requested.

It was reported that the surgeon had a difficulty to remove the impactor (P/N: 221750041) after inserted the Gription cup during the THA surgery on May 15th, 2019 of the patient?s right hip joint. The surgeon attempted to remove the impactor however it moved with the cup (the surgeon did not press the round button). The surgeon removed the impactor with the cup by striking with a hammer because the surgeon could not remove it manually. The same issue occurred even the surgeon attempted insert the cup according to the procedure again. After that, the surgeon attached the impactor to the cup loosely for removing easily, inserted the cup and removed the impactor successfully, fixed the cup with 3 screws. The surgery was completed within a 30 minutes surgical delay and there was no adverse consequence to the patient. No further information is available.

Email notification received. The surgeon constitutes a complaint about the Corail, Trilock and Accolade system. As stated in the email, "When extracting Corail broaches, sometimes the lateral shoulder gets hung up under tough cancellous bone. During the final centimeter of engagement the broach can go somewhat valgus and sit underneath tough bone. The shape of the broach and teeth can make it difficult to remove a broach like this." He also commented that for larger sizes (13 and 14 mentioned) in tight femurs it can be difficult to introduce the stem in anterior approach because those sizes are too long and straight. Is it possible to shorten them? DOI: Unknown DOR: Unknown Unknown affected side

Pinnacle Claim Submission Form, medical records and implant sticker sheets received. After review of medical records, the patient was revised to address metal toxicity and progressive pain. X-rays were taken prior to the revision revealing what looked like a large bubble of osteolysis over the lateral shoulder of the implant as well as some flattening of the calcar. Operative findings include a large pocket of bursal fluid containing about 10 cc of clear, straw colored fluid. There was a significant amount of sandy-type material over the areas correlating with the osteolytic area on the x-ray. Finally, there were some scar tissue and a small amount of granulation tissue between the cup and liner. DOI: Sep 16, 2009 - DOR: Nov 30, 2016 (Left Hip)

Pinnacle claim submission form and Medical records received. After review of medical records, the patient was revised to address a large fluid collection and metal-on-metal trunnion reaction. Revision note reported an extensive amount of joint fluid, damaged anterior aspect of the abductor muscle, necrotic-appearing bone and tissue, and an 8mm ring of black trunnion wear at the base of the head. An extended trochanteric osteotomy was done to remove the stem; however, a distal portion broke off as it was very well fixed to the femoral component. A cable was placed distal to the osteotomy to avoid further fracture. The extensive damage from the MOM reaction required an extended operating time of 6 hours. DOI: Apr 04, 2013; DOR: Jun 22, 2018; Right hip

It was reported that the surgeon performed patients original surgery. He believed it was done somewhere around 17-18 years prior. An article/literature was received entitled "Results of a hydroxyapatite?coated femoral stem (Corail) in Chinese: a minimum 10?year follow?up" was reviewed for MDR reportability on 21-May-2019. The study involves 92 hips (81 patients). Corail stems were placed in al patients. The manufacturer of the acetabular cup and liner are unknown at this time. Results: -2 patients suffered dislocation (closed reduction) -2 patients suffered DVTs -1 patient suffered a periprosthetic fracture following a fall at 3 years post op (plate placed-unknown location of fracture) -3 patients reported pain (no revision was noted) -2 patients underwent a revision due to liner wear at 10 years (unknown manufacturer of the liner/cup)

It was also reported that the tibial tray looks to be loose on x-ray, so the surgeon revised the tibial tray. The tray popped out after a few moderate taps around the base of the tray. It was reported that the white sigma tibial impactor was broken during calibration of the tibial component.

The primary surgery was performed on May 13th, 2019 via THA. It was reported that there was no problem at postoperative X-ray just after the primary surgery, however it was detected that a fracture line from greater trochanter to lesser trochanter. Thus, the revision surgery was performed on May 23rd, 2019 by replacing the head (P/N: 136532310), the stem (P/N: L971110) to C-STEM AMT. The cup was retained. The surgery was completed without a surgical delay. As for Dr?s view, there was a possibility that the fracture occurred because the Corail stem was inserted in the retrotorsion, the final rasp position and the insertion position might change if the Corail collared stem was inserted as there was no merkmal for antetorsion adjustment. Possible cause: there was a possibility by selecting the High Offset Stem that the gluteus maximus was pulled, a torsional stress was added, and the fracture occurred. Pinnacle claim submission form, sticker sheets and medical records received via CD shipment last 08 Apr 2019. After review of medical records, the patient was revised to address right hip pain, stiffness, instability and metal-on-metal disease. Operative findings include approximately 200 ml of brown fluid, a large pseudotumor, trunnionosis around the trunnion at the head and neck junction and large amount of metallosis between the cup and liner. Pathology reports confirm the metallosis. Radiograph impression of the right hip, greater trochanter insufficiency fracture with osteolysis around the proximal aspect of the femoral component. Patient previously had a resurfacing hip. Manufacturer unknown. DOI: Oct 23, 2006 - DOR: Oct 24, 2016 (Right Hip)

Pinnacle claim submission form, sticker sheets and medical records received via CD shipment last 08 Apr 2019. After review of medical records, the patient was revised to address infection, sepsis and to place an antibiotic spacer. Operative findings include large pockets of pus, abscesses and minor metal stains in the soft tissues but no gross evidence of metallosis. A trochanteric osteotomy was required to remove the stem which caused the proximal medial femoral cortex to fracture, fragment and shatter. Two Synthes cables were required. Competitor cement spacer was used. Pathology reports indicate fibrosis and marked acute inflammation. DOI: Jul 31, 2006 - DOR: May 9, 2012 (Right Hip)

Pinnacle Claim Submission Form and Medical Record received. The patient has had difficulty with pain. After review of Medical Record, the patient was revised to address failed left total hip arthroplasty. Revision notes reported that the patient was found to have obvious evidence of a loose femoral component. There was micromotion present at the stem. The stem was removed with a back slap device placed through the proximal hole without any bone loss. There was no evidence of osteal integration along the length of the stem. Acetabular component was found be well fixed and well positioned. There was no gross evidence of infection or any obvious metal - on- metal response. Serial radiographs of the femoral component showed evidence of subsidence and some periprosthetic lucency. DOI: Jan 13, 2009 - DOR: Sep 14, 2010 (Left hip)

Revision of PFC tibial components.; Dr. Chris Morrey; Cairns Private Hospital 28/05/2019. Primary surgery date: 03/10/2017. Revision for; Pain, loosening. Patient report : " A coloscopy was done : it was negative. After 2 years, 2 hip prosthesis Pinnacle Stem Corail KA were implanted. Then, a new coloscopy was done which showed a tumor 8 cms in the transverse colon . During the subtotal colectomy surgery on 11 September, metastases in the liver were detected. During the surgery, I was informed that the titanium is a component of the 2 prosthesis implanted. This cancer is very aggressive : I had metastases at the brain. My life is in danger. It is impossible to prove the link between my cancer and the titanium dioxyde but researchers affirmed that there is a link beetwen the initiation of the colon cancer and the presence of titane in the body. A chimiotherapy and radiotherapy treatment were decided. "

Dear Team I was present at a revision hip today at Wrightington. Surgeon Mr Gambhir Op date 24/1/19 Left Thr revision liner fracture. The patient presented with a Ceramic fracture a few months ago. It was determined to be a rim fracture. The liner was removed and fracture pieces collected from the surround tissue. The pinnacle shell was well fixed as was the Corail stem. A liner exchanged was completed. A 36 by 58 mm liner was removed and a 36 neutral marathon poly liner was implanted and fixed well. The head was replaced with a delta TS head 36 by +12. Please see pic for stickers. The original op notes and stickers were not available, no x rays can be forwarded at this time. The retrieved implant was disposed of locally. No patient demographics are available.

As above Surgeon Mr Gambhir Hospital Wrightington A suggestion would be to have all trays placed in Sterile tins to prevent this.

It was reported that during a Left Knee Revision using the Depuy TC3/Revision MBT construct, when the 5 Degree Femoral adapter was being tightened to the Femoral TC3 implant, the Torq wrench broke, and the plastic tip of the torq wrench became seperated from the wrench, and stuck onto the 5 Degree Adapter. It was determined by the Surgeon that because the Torq wrench broke, it was considered contaminated, and no longer sterile. The plastic tip of the torq wrench being stuck on the adapter also made the 5 degree adapter unsterile. Another torq wrench was found, but was unsterile, and was then processed for sterility using standard hospital protocol. This delayed the case 45 mins. DOI: Dec 20, 2018 DOR: Unknown Left Knee

It was reported that the Dr. texted the Sales Rep and said "I have a metal on metal revision hip coming up I wanted to see what my headliner options were". After a brief phone call, the surgeon decided that he was going to try to preserve the cup, remove the metal liner and preoperative plan was to trial and replace liner with +4/10° and +9 32mm head. Dr. could not remove metal liner using a AB extractor, reciprocating saw, and bone tamps. Dr. decided to remove entire cut implant Zimmer acetabular cup and liner and also implant +5 TS 32 mm head. Nothing was said about the metal on metal liner but there was an obvious understanding that it was an issue based on the explant and tissue surrounding the cup. The patient was revised to address fallen down on his right knee, pain and loosening of the tibial component at the cement to implant interface. Cement manufacturer was competitor.Surgeon decided he would do a revision surgery and fix a suspected loose tibial Tray. Intraoperatively surgeon discovered that the Tibial tray was loose and explanted. Once the implant was out Surgeon states that the Anterior Tibial plateau and tuberacle where fractured. The Fracture was reduce and screws were inserted into the bone to achieve reduction. A new poly insert was cemented on top of the Tibial bone so the femur would have a surface to articulate on. Surgeon states that he planned on having the patient non weight bearing and in a brace that kept him in extension for 6-8 weeks until the fracture healed. At that point another revision would be required to implant another Tibial Tray. DOI: 14 years ago; DOR: Jan 7, 2019; Right Knee

During a Hip Replacement Procedure at Tygerberg Hospital, we required the use of a cement restrictor (Biostop). The surgeon requested a Biostop, size 14. When the product was opened and taken out of the sterile packaging, it appeared warped, as though it had melted. The surgeon opted to use a size 12 in place of the damaged implant, at no compromise to the patient. It has since become evident that a similar situation had happened on 30 November 2018, however the product and packaging was thrown away by the hospital before details of the implant could be recorded.

The primary surgery was performed in Mar 2010 via THA (date of primary surgery was unknown). The surgeon decided to perform the revision surgery by replacing the stem due to suspected ARMD because liquid came to be accumulated in the hip joint repeatedly even if it was draining out since the patient was overturned in Aug 2018. It seemed allergic reaction. The surgeon judged it need to replace the stem (P/N: 900533210), the head (P/N: 152190062), the liner (manufactured by Stryker) because the patient had an allergic response to cobalt chromium by patch test. Thus, the revision surgery was performed by washing out on the patient?s hip joint and replacing the implants on Jan 8th 2019. It was confirmed that the surrounding tissue of the hip joint was almost necrotic and there was considerable accumulation of pus. In addition, the head/neck junction was corroded and was discolored black. The surgery was completed without problems. No further information was provided by the hospital.

Consumer Verbatim:- Respected Managing Director, My left hip was planted in Dec 2008 and the product was purchased from Johnson and Johnson company. While purchasing the product, I was assured by the company that the product life was 15 years. But within 10 years of hip implant sudden pain started in my hip and now a days it is unbearable. The product life is remained 05 years but acute pain has started in my thigh and hip and unable to do my work properly and sleep well. You're requested to tell me how I can get my hip implanted while the due date is still not ended of the product. I have also come to know that johnson and johnson company recalled the hip implant products and gave compensation to patients. Please consider my request and help me so that I can be helped. ASR Claim letter received. Claim letter alleges pain, tissue reaction and allergic reaction to nickel and cobalt chloride. The patient was implanted with an ASR prosthesis with a non-cemented stem despite declaring that she has an allergy to metal components. Radiograph reported a prosthesis with a undersized dome of the acetabulum. Scintigraphy result shows suspected infection of the cup and had elevated inflammatory index. The patient had a revision due to the mobilization of the right hip cup, allergic reaction and nosocomial infection. Patient made legal action against the surgeon and hospital due to inadequate precaution and lack of control over the suitability of the implanted prosthesis. PPF and Medical Records received. PPF has no allegations. After review of Medical Records, patient was revised to address failed right total hip arthroplasty. Revision notes stated that inspection of the hip revealed a significant high volume synovitis and reactive inflammatory fluid volume.The synovitis was consistent with the hyperplastic response having an orange-tinged coloring and the fluid volume was dark brown fluid. Exploration of the hip revealed significant cortical lysis and lytic changes superior to the shell. The metal liner was extremely difficult to remove and took the bulk of the surgical time. There was lytic changes and cortical lysis that extended down along the posterior femoral wall extending into the lesser trochanter and corrosion below the metal head and neck. DOI: Jan 10, 2006 - DOR: Aug 03, 2017 (Right Hip)

In the patient's surgery (initials of the patient ARR), a RECLAIM hip prosthesis was used, almost at the end of the procedure, when all the prostheses were inserted, at the moment of fusion between the proximal and distal prostheses of the femur, the device used to make this fusion did not work, the doctor tried several times (for about an hour and a half). Afterwards, it was detected that the device was broken, so the doctor put the screw that goes in the prosthesis and he finalized the procedure. The doctor did not effect the fusion between the prosthesis proximal and distal of the femur, which is very important for this procedure, and also the great differential of this material, leaving the whole team dissatisfied with our company. The biggest problem with all this was the patient, because the prosthesis was not placed 100% in the correct way according to the surgical technique. Product information: code and lot: unk

The surgeon implanted the Corail stem described above. He then wanted to remove the stem and replace with a larger size 13. When he tried to engage the thread of the Corail extractor into the implant it would not connect. There was no thread inside the hole of the Corail implant. The Corail extractor thread was checked for damage so it can be confirmed that this instrument was not the issue. The surgeon had to leave the stem in situ. He has confirmed that there was no compromise to the patient. His rationale for wanting to extract and upsize was to better match the opposite leg that already had a Corail implant. Delay to surgery was approximately 30 minutes. There are no additional patient information available,

In the patient's surgery (initials of the patient ARR), a RECLAIM hip prosthesis was used, almost at the end of the procedure, when all the prostheses were inserted, at the moment of fusion between the proximal and distal prostheses of the femur, the device used to make this fusion did not work, the doctor tried several times (for about an hour and a half). Afterwards, it was detected that the device was broken, so the doctor put the screw that goes in the prosthesis and he finalized the procedure. The doctor did not effect the fusion between the prosthesis proximal and distal of the femur, which is very important for this procedure, and also the great differential of this material, leaving the whole team dissatisfied with our company. The biggest problem with all this was the patient, because the prosthesis was not placed 100% in the correct way according to the surgical technique. Product information: code and lot: unk Unknown hip

Attune Navigated Total Knee Replacement: Zsolt Hermann, Belverdale Private Hospital, 28/01/2019. When the surgeon tried to put the blade through the slot on the SP2 Femoral Cutting Block, it was hard to get the blade through smoothly. Zsolt described it as tight unevenly through the cutting slot. The event occurred at approx 2 pm on the 28/1/19. They tired a different blade with the same result. It was then established that it must be the cutting block which may be at fault. Looking at the cutting block afterwards JJM Rep could see that the metal surfaces on the cutting slot are burred. See attached photo. The procedure could be continued with this cutting block, it just made it harder than would be expected. Patient outcome was successful. The desired outcome was achieved. 2-3 minutes delay in the procedure This instrument will be isolated when received back by the loans team, and then sent away for assessment.

We opened an implant with Ref: 9655-12-845 LOT: 8959248 Exp 10/23 (Marathon Cemented Cup 45mm OD / 28mm ID), on 29/1/19 at around 10:30am. Again, it was the same problem as Matt has listed below. The X-ray marker did not fit correctly onto the implant, and this has now happened multiple times to Mr Phillipson. I witnessed this whilst present in the case and can categorically say that it could not have been a user error ? the marker did not fit. Due to the previous frustrations that Mr Phillipson has had with this, he decided his only option therefore was to implant without the X-ray marker as previously he has opened another implant and it has been the same problem.

values.text: Person who is trained and licensed to provide health care to humans. Includes: doctor, nurse, dentist, pharmacist, midwife; excludes: veterinarian.

Reports sent by health professionals or patients when an adverse effect has occurred in a patient taking one or more medicines. These have also been referred to as adverse drug reaction (ADR) reports or adverse event (AE) reports.
The science and activities relating to the detection, assessment, understanding and prevention of adverse effects or any other possible drug-related problems.
A suspect drug is a drug which is thought to be associated with the adverse event in question.

Any unintended outcome that seems to be associated with treatment, including negative or positive effects. This term has come to be used exclusively in the sense of ‘adverse effect’; this loses the important dimension of potential reference to unintended positive effects as well as linguistically masking the adverse element of a negative side effect.
Symptoms or disease for which a remedy or treatment is advisable or necessary.
A concomitant drug is a drug which the patient is using at the time of the adverse event in question. A concomitant drug won’t have any relation with the adverse event.

Any negative or harmful occurrence that takes place during treatment, that may or may not be associated with a medicine. Note: A fall could be such an event that may – or may not – have any association with a medicine.
